monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: My teacher, the meaning of curdling is as follows: When yogurt emerges [from milk], it is something the Lord of the Worlds has created through His power and might, because, let us say, neither medicine nor the so-called scientists can achieve fermentation without rennet (liban).

You add rennet or yogurt, and then the milk turns into yogurt; if it doesn’t curdle… will the milk become yogurt on its own? No, it won’t! So, it was the Lord of the Worlds who did that; through His power on a certain day; that is the day of the curdling of the milk, and on another day comes the 'fermentation of truffles'... the 'fermentation of truffles'.
Truffles have no seeds, my teacher. The truffles—we call them čime, in Turkish they say keme here in Urfa. We, the Arabs, say čime. Yes, these truffles have no seeds.

So, when it rains one day, the Lord of the Worlds—through His power and might—places their seeds into the soil during this rain. On that day, the truffle seeds come into being. That’s what people say—I haven’t seen it with my own eyes, of course, but that’s how the story goes.

On that day, when it rains, they also say: ‘This year there will be many truffles, a good blessing (from God).’ And indeed, the truffles begin to multiply, and people go out to the fields to collect them.

And they come to the city, to Urfa, to sell them. Who eats them, eats them; who eats them does not sell them, and who gathers a lot comes and sells them. We call this the 'fermentation of truffles.'How much do they sell them for? – A kilo of truffles here in Urfa – there are two or three types – let’s say, there are small ones and large ones, about the size of a potato, quite large.

A kilo costs 10 lira, even 12 lira. If there are many, the price drops to 7. The small ones are sold for 5 lira. If there are few, the price rises to 20 lira — that is, when there are (almost) none. When there are many, they become cheap.

So, the truffles—those are the truffles. How do we prepare them? Here, we bring the truffles… some people make kebab out of them. They bring meat to be minced and then mince it together with the truffles, mixing it all together.

And… you saw yesterday evening how we made the kebab… they add pure minced meat, a simple kebab, just truffles and meat. They cook it and eat it. They peel the truffles and mince them together with the meat.

As for us, we have never made kebab out of them. I’m not telling you that we ever did; but they say that’s how it’s done. What we do is take them and chop them very finely; we wash them well along with the skin, we don’t peel them, we chop them very finely, we say… small.
We roast them a little in clarified butter and add eggs; we add eggs and eat them like that. That’s how I have eaten them before, but I have never eaten kebab made from them

They say truffles are good; they are good for the eyes. If you cut one in half like a potato and squeeze the juice into your eye, it is good for the eyes—a remedy for the eyes. So for someone whose eyes hurt a little or water.

The one who sees poorly, who says, ‘My eye sees like this,’—we say ‘cloudy’ (in Turkish)—so the one who has poor vision. He squeezes truffle juice into his eye, and they say, they say it is a remedy… for the eyes.
